alert.note: Alert for Oconee (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Advisory issued September 03 at 6:25AM EDT until September 03 at 11:15AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 915 AM EDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...Portions of northeast Georgia and upstate South Carolina, including the following counties, in northeast Georgia, Rabun and Stephens. In upstate South Carolina, Oconee. * WHEN...Until 915 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 614 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. Enhanced stream rises area ongoing across western Oconee County in South Carolina and eastern Stephens and Rabun counties in northeast Georgia. Tributaries and streams could be or will be threatening to cross roadways such as Gryer Branch affecting Cleveland Pike Road, and Toxaway Creek possibly approaching North Horseshoe Bridge Road. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Toccoa, Martin, Avalon, Sky Valley, Tallulah Falls, Tallulah Gorge State Park, Oconee State Park, Lake Hartwell, Long Creek, Mountain Rest, Pine Mountain, Eastanolee and Boydville. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding or landslides threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed.
